Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Unmodified Android Honeycomb OS, ports galore, including full-size SD card slot, swappable battery, solid hardware
Cons: Software and apps not as polished as iPad's, lackluster battery life, thick and heavy compared to other slates, basic, unflashy design
The 16 GB Wi-Fi-only Toshiba Thrive lacks many of the proprietary bells and whistles found on other Android tablets, but that simplicity is what critics like about the slate: It's very close to a straightforward Android Honeycomb environment, and a forthcoming update will upgrade that to Android 4.0 Ice Cream Sandwich. Other touches, such as the swappable battery, myriad ports -- full-sized HDMI, USB and SD card slots are all onboard -- and the straightforward design add credence to its reputation as a "Geek's machine. ... " The 1,280-by-800-pixel IPS display earns praise for its wide viewing angles. ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black

I debated buying this due to the fact that I already have a laptop. I really wanted something easier to carry and with a usb. I researched and researched. While I loaded a free geocaching program on it, and it works great, I am unable to upload caches from the tablet to my delorme due to the fact that it recognizes the sd card but the sd card on the delorme is for maps only. It did however upload caches to my Garmin Oregon 450. I was also able to upload from a gpx file straight from an email pocket query and from a zip drive to view on the tablet. Next I wanted to watch movies. I found another free program and with some work discovered I could convert my dvd's to a playable format on my thrive. I presently have abou ... t 6 movies on a sd card to watch at anytime, although I must say the sound quality is very low. The battery charges quickly and lasts a long time. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.ReviewTitle: A decent alternative to the iPad
Item.Review:
Pros: Competitive price. Good bells and whistles.
Cons: Sound quality. No flash for camera.
I can download and use any of the apps I previously used on my Droid; thus, I already understand how to use and navigate each application. The Thrive tablet is multifunctional because it also works as an excellent eBook reader, with back-lighting and adjustable fonts. It can be used as a camera although it did not have built-in flash. It has a front facing camera for Skype. This is my first tablet so I still have some challenges on how to access certain features and configure apps. The battery doesn't last the full 11 hours as was marketing; maybe closer to 8. All in all, I'm happy with the purchase and would recommend it as a cheaper iPad.

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Speed, size, portability, front facing cam for Skype
Cons: Cam resolution, shutter speed, battery charger
I bought mine at a Best Buy Mobile store on the reccomendation of one of their clerks who seemed very knowlegable. I got it on Black Friday. After I bought it I went home and read the reviews online. Everyone was talking about the thickness and weight of this Tablet. Bunk! Replaceable batteries and all those USB, HDMI and card ports would be too thick to try and put into an iPad or one of the other Tablets I looked at.
A suggestion for Toshiba: This has a dedicated charging device. Get past it (looks like the same charger for my laptop!). Get into the mini USB charger. Not really a Con, since batterylife is fantastic!
Performance is incredible (Better ... than my Toshiba Sattelite laptop - 2 years old) and is a great wi-fi reciever! I had the hotspot/tethering service added to my Samsung Galaxy S and have found the increased utility when Im away from my home network or even my business network is amazing.
Watch what apps you load on it tho. Words with Friends (an incredibly addicting game) does not run on this tablet. I recently purchased the paid version of the preinstalled Quick Office App - it is now Quickoffice Pro and love it's functionality.
Fast, large screen, easy to use right out of the box. Thickness actually makes it a bit easier to hold onto. Not a "con" at all.
Seems Toshiba has thought of everything! I dont sit there and think, "I wish they had done this, or had designed this a different way..." Some people talked about in their reviews that the lights were "distracting". I would suggest that those people get distracted too easily.
I havent figured out if it is me or the Thrive yet. But the cameras seem to be low rez, and click the shutter button to take a picture and go get a cup of coffee. When you come back, the shutter might have snapped the picture! Are all tabs this slow or is it just the Thrive? I have not yet been able to take an un-blurred photo. I dont see a fitting for a tripod...
I bought a Kindle Fire for my wife (purse si ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review: I have had this tablet for 2 weeks now and absolutely love it! I had my doubts about its performance having owned a generic tablet that was a very poor performer. With the Thrive you can watch Netflix movies, download torrents, play Onlive video games, browse the internet, Skype and almost everything you can do on a traditional computer. I love the two cameras for Skype. You can switch between the two to show the person you are Skyping with your surroundings without the turning the tablet around! The rear facing camera could use better placement but that is a very small gripe. The cameras are not high-def but I'm not planning on using it to take many photos or videos, I have a digital camera for that. The touch is super responsive, you can use just your finger nail to help reduce finge ... r prints from building up on the screen. The screen itself is very nice, I can watch high-def movies on it and see no difference in resolution when compared to my 50 plasma. Since the Thrive has a full sized HDMI port, you can watch your shows or play games on your big screen tv. It also has a full size SD card slot that allows you to pull your SD card from your camera or laptop and insert it without adapters. And if you have a micro or mini SD card they work just as well with an adapter. There is a full size USB port so you can use thumb drives and a mini USB port so you can charge your phone or other devices. I love the ribbed rubbery like grip on the back. I can hold it in one hand near vertical without fear of it slipping. The back also comes off and you can buy different colored covers seperately. The battery is also removable so you can replace it when it doesn't hold a charge or keep an extra charged one ready to go. Speaking of the battery, this thing has great battery life. I haven't really timed it but I can go for quite some time before having to charge it. Of course the charge depends on how much video, wi-fi, bluetooth, etc you use on the tablet. For regular surfing and just reading e-books I would estimate at least 8 hours. Turn off the wi-fi and use it as just a reader, with the screen auto-brightness enabled you can probably get closer to 12 hours. I'm sure there are a hundred other features and things about the Thrive that I love that is slipping my mind right now. But if you are looking for an Android tablet and can afford it, I highly recommend the Toshiba Thrive. You will not be dissapointed. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review: Using money from the swingset she sold, my daughter bought this tablet for school and entertainment. I believe it's a great product and she really likes it, especially the multi-touch. The file manager took her a while to learn but it's excellent as well. Much has been said about the USB ports and they are all that and more. I connected a non-powered 4 port hub and was able to run a keyboard, mouse and 4 gig flash drive all at the same time. I tried an external hard drive but it is NTFS and would not work. I don't have an external FAT32 drive to try which reminds me that the flash drives must be formatted FAT32. Overall a great product and am going to echo some of other features such as the feel of the back. The LEDs are ok to have. The size of the power supply isn't a big deal. Battery li ... fe is very acceptable. The weight doesn't bother her but I would like to see it a little lighter. Size is okay but the 10.1" screen is wonderful. We're going on vacation and instead of lugging around two laptops like usual, we are taking this. In combination with our smart phones, we will be connected well enough to enjoy being on vacation. We wish there was a 4.5 star, but still, it doesn't get any better for the price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Expansion ports; Display; price
Cons: Battery life; Weight; No 3g
This is a very versitile tablet. I do wish, however, that it could have internet access in non-wifi areas. When using it recently in an airport, the antenna was not strong enough to pull in the airport wifi signal. The volume control should allow higher volumes, especially for use on airplanes. While watching a movie through ear phones the max volume was too low to overcome the aircraft noise. The recessed earphone port does not allow the use of a splitter. It should not be recessed.

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Charges quickly; Gps; Solid Construction; Plenty of android apps; Two cameras; Full size HDMI; Full size USB and mini; Large screen
Cons: Battery can drain fast; Standby eats battery; Cameras placed poorly; Heavy
Got 2 of these - one for me, one for the lady - and we are very happy with this purchase/product. My first tablet. She also has a kindle. Opted for this instead of a new color e-book reader. Her biggest complaint is the weight difference, but this tablet has a 10inch glass screen. It does get a little heavy in the hand.
Web/email browsing is fast and easy. Not much else to say. If you use google chrome or other android browsers, should be an easy learning curve. Mapping trips is easy to do with GPS functionality and the large screen. No more fumbling wit ... h tiny GPS navigators.
I love to read marvel comics on this, have been reading paper comics all my life and never thought digital comics would be as good. They're better. Bright/crisp colorful images, can't cheat by accidentally looking ahead at the next cells, so every page turn is a surprise.
We noticed battery life is between 2-3 hours with continuous use. It doesn't take long to charge, but it will still suck down battery in Stand-By mode. Power down completely before you fall asleep at night or you'll need to recharge tomorrow morning. Rebooting takes 30 seconds and is ready to use the instant the home screen appears (both on boot and stand-by recovery).
Text entry can be troublesome, but the voice recognition works well on regular words (struggles when dictating email addresses and acronyms). In-line text editing is a pain having to drag begin/end selection arrows. The onscreen keyboard doesn't have a delete key, but i'm sure there is a way around that i haven't yet discovered.
All in all, awesome tablet. Exceeds my expectations, but not a laptop replacement. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.ReviewTitle: Good, but a few issues keep it from being great
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy to use, cheap price
Cons: Battery life could be longer, and horrible at displaying pictures and videos.
Picked up one of these instead of an iPad mainly because of the flash issue with apple. For web browsing, apps and general use, it's a 5. Very quick, and lots of apps to get you where you want to be.
But...one of the reasons I bought it was for personal presentations where I'd load pics/videos to an SD card or USB stick (one of my reasons for purchasing this one 'cause it had the ports) and display them.
Problem is twofold; a) it doesn't play most video formats out there. I tried AVI, WMV, MOV and several others not finding one that would play. and the b) part is that it apparently doesn't know how to scale pictures. Quite honestly they look horribl ... e, like they were taken through a lens smeared with grease. The pics were taken with a professional Nikon and display beautifully on every other device I've tried them on including the iPad. This is pretty amazing given that their Blu-Ray players are outstanding in this regard and Nvidia is supposed to know a thing or two about video. It's internal cameras are also pretty bad a well so I can't even shoot things native to the device.
So for me unfortunately, this one may have to go back in favor of a laptop if Toshiba doesn't respond to my queries on their website, 'cause it simply will be of no real use for me. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Full Size Ports, Customization
Cons: Port Cover is clumsy when removed.
This is a fantastic piece of hardware. The clincher for me was the full size USB port.
Prior to buying this I had read mixed things about the tablet powering an external hard drive. At the store, I tested the tablet with a Toshiba drive formatted as NTFS. This however did not work.
That day I purchased a 1 TB Western Digital My Passport. Brought it home formatted it as exFAT, took it back to Best Buy, plugged it in and the tablet read it no problem. The trick is in the formatting.
The Toshiba File Manager makes finding and organizing your files a snap.
USB keyboard worked immediately upon plugging it in. No special settings required.
The tablet has done everything ... I have thrown at it so far. The screen has a beautiful picture quality and the battery life has been decent so far.
The tablet is easy to hold and not overly heavy. This tablet cannot be compared to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 or the iPad 2 in terms of size because this tablet is meant for a different niche of the market. This tablet is for people like me that want the ports, and the ability to do different things with our tablets. The ports are well worth the slight difference in thickness as compared to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 or the iPad 2.
I did the firmware update right away and there have been no issues whatsoever with the tablet waking up from sleep.
I would recommend this tablet to anyone who wants the ability to customize their tablet and almost endless possibilities. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:

Cons: No netflix or hulu (yet), no flash for the camera.
I love the apps and the app store for android. the Tablet is fast and easy to use wherever there is WIFI. I'm so glad I got this instead of a netbook. It's easier to carry, has a great battery life and tons of free apps that are fun to use. I recomend you get one. The fact that it has the usb, hdmi, and sd card slot are what sold me and I'm glad i bought it. Still waiting on the Netflix and Hulu app, that would make this even more pleasurable to use. My only gripe is that it doesn't have a flash for the great camera, and the speakers could have been a bit louder, but I mainly use headphones anyway.

I have had the tablet for about two full weeks now.. In one word, the tablet is AWESOME! It is super fast, very touch responsive, great display, just everything is fantastic.
The first week, I was experiencing the "waking" issue. However, the past week, this has not been a problem at all. I believe Toshiba came out with an update that has fixed it (has been an update just about every other day).
I love all the extras this tablet has to offer. That is the main reason I went with the Thrive. Another thing I really like about the Thrive is the fact the top of the tablet is highlight. I mean the "silver" around the camera kinda always lets me know, what is up, and what is down. ...
Don't let the negative (mainly Apple fanboys from the look of it) review make you pass on the Thrive. It really is a homerun! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: functionality
Cons: Can't think of anything important
This is a highly functional, feature packed tablet that can do things the Ipad can't. I am a professional photographer that is on the go all the time. I have used Toshiba laptops for years with great success and checked out the Thrive when it first came out. This tablet offers features that are very useful in my field. Good screen, rugged construction, full size HDMI port, a USB port, AND fully expandable memory using inexpensive SD cards. I have had this several months and have used it nearly everyday. It has stood up to everything I have thrown at it. Downloading photos directly to the Thrive is a snap with just about any card reader. SD's go directly into the provided slot and all others through a card reader via ... USB port. PDAnet also offers a beta Tablet app that allows you to connect an android phone via bluetooth that allows the Thrive to be used on 3G/4G networks!. I use a 4G HTC Thunderbolt and it works flawlessly. The open Android market offers all the apps I have needed including a great Adobe Photoshop app that works fine if I need something in a hurry. The tablet is 3 oz. heavier and a little thicker that an Ipad, so if super thin is your thing, this may not work. But, if you want true functionality, the Thrive delivers. Battery life is pretty good, but don't try to go more that a full day on a charge. The file manager is a very well thought out piece of software that helps manage, photos, videos and downloads etc.. Connecting flash drives and SD cards to move things on and off the Thrive is sooo easy and fast. Also, the Thrive runs Adobe flash so videos can be viewed directly from websites instead of having to rely on Youtube to view them. Also the battery can be replaced by you. . So no more sending the tablet back for this to be performed leaving you without your tablet for extended periods. Like I said, if you want eye candy, get an Ipad, if you want a truly versatile tablet, you can't go wrong with a Toshiba Thrive. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: SD card slot; Speed; boot time; USB HMDI ports
Cons: Weight; No good MS Office; Some embedded video issue
The Thrive excels in the living room, near the couch. It's made for news, email, chat, Facebook, YouTube and streaming NetFlix and movies to your TV. Maybe it can be tethered to a phone for wireless data, but mostly it's a netbook replacement you take from one WiFi spot to another. For GPS navigation, you'll need an app with offline maps as Google's won't work offline.
Unlike the iPad2, it doesn't have 3G wireless (or the cost). But it does have USB, HDMI, SD Card and onboard speakers, which the iPad does not. This makes it very versatile. Anything USB works: Flash drives, portable hard drives, cameras, etc. Get the NetFlix app and stream movies in HD. Plug y ... our TV into the HDMI - it just works. Use your Bluetooth cell phone as a remote control, or to transfer files. The SD slot means the onboard memory is upgradable to 128 GB or more. I haven't tried video chat yet, so the advantage of a 2MP front camera escape me. I've no clue what rear one's for. With a USB wireless keyboard and mouse it's not a half-bad netbook replacement, would be if there were an Android MS Office app. QuickOffice HD is only half-way there.
The rear is rubberized, so it won't get scratched and it's not slippery. But the weight and balance make it hard to use without resting it on your lap or something else. That's the trade-off for all those ports and the bigger screen. Even so, they could've made the case edges smoother or designed a comfortable place for your hand. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.ReviewTitle: Great value, great performance and a solid build
Item.Review:
Pros: Screen quality, grip treatment of the back/cover, excellent connectivity and price
Cons: Booting from a cold start could be faster but it's still OK
What I was most concerned with in shopping for a tablet:
- size - price - connectivity - display quality - support
If you google around about screen bleed you will find that the tablet sector is experiencing the same type of nonsense the LCD flat-panel computer monitor industry went through many years ago; e.g. uneven backlighting and light bleed. Be wary of super thin and flexible chassis designs of the more popular tablets; screen performance can be greatly effected by "flex".
I demo'd them all. iPads are a closed system and WAY over priced. Don't get me wrong, I love Apple products and ow ... n several but for a tablet I decided upon an Android based one pretty easily. It's an open platform and anyone that complains about the lack of android apps has their head in sand. Android is flourishing. I like Samsung screen quality but the light bleed issue is still a coin toss with them and the chassis flex coupled with the lack of being able to add SD memory made it a no-go. I looked at everything including the Playbook and settled on the Motorola Xoom FE first. You could add memory, the screen looked awesome #initially# and the platform seemed pretty peppy for sub $400. I was stoked. Upon further use I started to notice the unacceptable screen bleed and clouding around the edges. It was really noticable when watcing movies or using darker apps in low light conditions. Sound on the built-in speakers on the Xoom was terrible and the max volume level was really bad too. I took back the first one and the replacement was even worse. So the Moto started off good but ended up a complete dud.
Enter the Toshiba Thrive 16 GB. What I like about this unit is the rubberized back for a much easier and safe handling experience. It might be thicker by a skoosh but it doesn't seem noticably heavier to me and my family. The full size ports are great and a really nice touch. The chassis seems markedly more stiff than most that are fab'd out of plastic and thinner. The screen is great and ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Price, Screen size, Battery Life, Simple to Use
Cons: Weight, OS presently lacks many drivers for USB devices
I purchased my Thrive about a month ago and so far am very happy with it. I restricted my consideration to Android tablets as, although I am very happy with other Apple products I own, I'm tired of being locked into Apple's proprietary market. Overall, it has lived up to everything I wanted it to be. The display is excellent, processor seems very fast, the USB port worked immediately with external storage, cameras are impressive, and there are ample useful apps in the Marketplace (lots of junk there too of course). Battery life is outstanding but of course you feel the weight for that. It is heavier than most tablets, however, the rubbery backing makes y ... our grip feel solid. Couple drawbacks you should be aware of though. I found the speakers pretty "tinny" sounding but it's great with headphones. Camera placement is an exceedingly poor location. Both are in the exact position a right handed person would tend to hold the tablet in landscape orientation. The USB port works for storage but presently does not work for much else (ie cameras, 3G USB dongles, etc). Some of this may be addressed in the next Android OS, Ice Cream Sandwich, due for rollout in October. You should also be aware that the cameras are not presently operational with some websites, (ie: Chatroulette, etc). I imagine this may be addressed as android tablets continue to expand in popularity and doubt this is restricted to the Thrive. Oh, if you presently use a 3G dongle for internet with a laptop, it will probably not presently work with this tablet. My workaround was to purchase a tiny Cradlepoint CTR35 wifi router, jack the 3G dongle into that, and then connect the tablet into the Wifi network created by the router. It worked immediately. The dongle issue could possibly resolved by the ICS rollout in October but who knows till it comes out. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.ReviewTitle: Those in the know will want this tablet
Item.Review:
Pros: More features than any other device
Cons: Bulkier
FIrst off it's a Toshiba, which, for those of you who have never owned one of their laptops, is a very good company. The 10 inch screen is very sharp, great resolution. Toshiba has managed to overcome the few shortcomings of Android OS issues with their own software. You can access thumb drives from a full sized USB port, and regularly swap out SD cards with their file manager program which is unique to this unit. I normally root these devices, and this is the first one I really haven't felt the need to. Toshiba has also supplied regular updates to their software, which has improved the device every time; it's not just bug fixes. You get external volume controls, which is a real plus if you have ever owned a phone or tab ... let that only has on screen volume control.
Probably the biggest selling point is the replaceable battery. Granted it won't be a cheap replacement, but the fact that you can buy the battery in a store and swap it out yourself is a major plus. If you are a power user, imagine the ability to have two batteries for your device. Battery life is extremely efficient. I am told it will last roughly 6-8 hours during constant use. However, personally I have never seen the thing drop below 30% throughout a days moderate to heavy usage.
There are a few cons. The first is the afore mentioned volume controls. They made the device so sleek sometimes it's hard to distinguish between the volume and power buttons by touch. I have found a few apps that do not work with the Thrive as of yet, such as Netflix. This is not Toshiba's fault, and eventually companies like NEtflix will get their software updated for all devices. And there is a workaround for that particular app.
The other issue that you will read in every review of the Thrive is the weight of the device. Yes, it's heavier than an IPad or a Galaxy. But, not that much heavier. We're talking a difference of ounces not pounds. Personally, the heft of such a device makes it feel a little sturdier, and it is def ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: SD Card Slot; Easy To Use; HDMI Port; Easy To Set Up; Removable battery; USB Port
Cons: Bulky
The full size SD card slot is awesome. Makes a 16GB Tablet into a 48GB Tablet for $40, and I can bring extra 32GB cards along for long trips if i need more movies. You can even get 64GB cards for $115 or 128 GB for $200 but 32 GB cards are super cheap.

However it isn't really signifantly heavier than the ipad 2 or other android tablets, it is just kind of thicker but easy to hold. The back is kind of rubberized (and replaceable), so i was using it with only a sleeve style case when not in use. A tablet with a case (like my wife's ipad 2 with snap cov ... er) is probably close to the thrive naked.
Battery life is good (6 hours or so) but not excellent (10 hours or so) like some devices. I guess you could get a spare battery for like $80 if you were really desperate, but for now I'm sticking with 6 hours. The charger is a little bulky (power brick) and has long cords. I wish it was more the ipad style wall charger with a short cord. I'm hoping i can find an aftermarket charger that is smaller with much shorter cords (who needs 10 feet of cord to charge a tablet?)
I got this for both home and work so i could do movies/media but also download files from the internet and put them on a flash drive as well as use RDP/VPN. So far it has exceeded my expectations. expand » « collapse

I love my Toshiba Thrive. It is faster, solid, user friendly and full of features. My wife has an Ipad 2, and to be honest the Ipad2 is faster than my Toshiba, but to deal with widget and customization there is not much difference.
I love Android 3.1 because you are free to do what ever you want. The 5 screens let you customize your tablet in any possible way. Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.ReviewTitle: Great but with a few hiccups
Item.Review:
Pros: Expandability, GPS, feels good in hand, Flash player, price
Cons: Sleep mode issues. Android app maket hasn't quite caught up the the Apple app store yet.
I had been debating between getting an iPad or an Android tablet. I was sold on the Thrive's expandability.
The SD card reader works great (although it can't play the .avi video files my camera makes). The USB port works well but it is limited. My 1.5 Tb external hard drive is apparently too big for the file manager to recognize. I could charge my iPod but of course it couldn't read it as an external drive. Make sure it works with your equipment before purchase.
The screen is great and responsive. The GPS also works great. I just went for a drive and it followed my location pretty smoothly. I really like ... the rubber back. It makes the tablet feel more durable. The speakers are pretty good for the size (better than the iPad).
I have had a problem with waking it up from sleep mode (I've read on some forums that others are having the same problem). In the three days I've had it, it wouldn't wake up three times. I had to take the battery out and then put it back in to restart the tablet. I imagine a fix will be coming soon (after all, the tablet just barely came out) but I'm planning on returning it before my 14 day grace period is over.
I see the Thrive as a really cool netbook replacement. If you already have a bunch of apple apps and don't need the ports, the iPad is probably the better choice. If you need the expandability and are comfortable with the android market, it's a great choice over the iPad. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: EVERYTHING!!!!!!!
Cons: ???????????
This tablet is AMAZING!!!! Not only is this thing easy on the wallet but it works like a tablet that cost much more. I will say that it isn't quite as slim as other tablets but honestly, who cares. The performance and ease of use are what are really important. First, there are three actual buttons on the side of the unit *power,* volume, and * orientation lock/unlock. Other than that all of the other buttons are on the touch screen and are VERY practically located. But what really sets this tablet apart from others are the multiple connections that are available.There is of course a place to plug in the power cord and right next to that a headphone jack. But right above that is the good stuff, a small plastic cover once removed reveal ... s a small USB slot, a full-sized USB slot, and a full-sized HDMI slot. And just around the corner from that is a large SD card slot. So needless to say connectivity and expandability are two great features. Not to mention the 2 cameras, one in front and one in back. I've got to say that once you turn this thing on and get into the actual usage the performance is amazing. The ability to read PDF., the amazing HD quality of the video, the responsiveness of the touchcreen,the long battery life are all the things that make this a GREAT buy, I have had this since Christmas and have not had any problems with it at all. I would and have recommend this Toshiba Thrive to anyone looking for an AMAZING tablet at an affordable price. From searching the web to streaming video to my TV via the fullsized HDMI port the Toshiba Thrive not only hits the mark but smashes it too toothpicks. expand » « collapse

First, I purchased a competitor's tablet from another vendor. After attempting to get it to sinc with my WiFI for two days I returned it to the vendor for a refund. A couple of days later I received an email from BestBuy offering this Toshiba Thrive Tablet. A read over a 100 reviews and decided I would try it. And, am I SATISFIED. It is great. I ordered it on-line at about 12:30 A.M. (Midnight) locally. At @10:30 A.M. I received an email from BestBuy tellilng me the Toshiba Thrive tablet was ready for pickup. I picked it up and within 3 minutes after unpacking it and turning it on it was working. It immediately sinced to my home WiFI. This tablet is awesome. It has an SD car ... d capability, mini USB, USB, and HDMI, ports built in. The competitor tablet didn't come with any of these capabilities. You have to pay extra for them. My only complaint is that the screen easily takes finger prints. But, from what I understand all of them do. If you are looking for a table that has WiFI capability I recommend this one. CONS: I cannot transfer music files from the actual Tablet to my SD card. I use the file manager, select copy, select the SD card, select paste and it does not work. Also, I do not like that when I use the browser, it automatically goes to the "app" site and there is not always a choice for the "full site" at the bottom. Im in love with my new tablet. ive had it for a little over a month and its been great. i love that i can hook up my hdmi to it and watch whatever i wanted to on my tv. it has a good battery life and lots of apps. the only app it doesnt have is mortal combat, which was the reason i bought the tablet to begin with. Even without Mortal Combat this tablet is the best.

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: full size ports, great screen, expandable
Cons: longer battery life in sleep mode, back cover is a bit challenging to remove, power button doesn't line up with the LED
I did a TON of research before purchasing this tablet. In fact, I bought two of them! This is the only tablet on the market that has full size ports-- USB, SD, and even full size HDMI port! This is great because you don't need special adapters for anything. You can just walk up to your TV and plug this thing into it with the same cable you have hooked up to your DVD player. It also has a mini usb if you ever need it, along with a docking port, and the typical earphone and AC jacks. Battery life is very good if you remember to shut the unit off. If you just let it go into standby, the battery will be dead ... in a day or so... I really need to check if there's a setting to adjust this. It comes packed with apps, and with 16g of memory, there's plenty of room for more. You can expand with any full size SD card, or even add a jump/thumb drive. The best part of the full size USB is that you can transfer files easily with a thumb/jump drive (something we all seem to have a desk drawer full of these days). The camera works great, probably the best in the industry. It also has a forward facing cam, but I haven't tried it yet. I know a lot of people say it's bulky/heavy, but this is only in comparison to the ipad. Personally, I like that it feels somewhat substantial in my hand. It's certainly not cumbersome, and with a portfolio case attached, it feels no different than any other tablet. If I had to do it over again, I'd buy this in a heartbeat. Don't waste your money on the 32g version. With how easy it is to add memory with a twenty dollar jump drive or a SD card, it's not worth paying for more internal memory. Oh ya, screen and responsiveness are unbeatable!
If you're looking for an alternative to an ipad without having to be married to itunes, this is your best option. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.ReviewTitle: Thrive - its not just for pleasure.
Item.Review: I use the Thrive for business - sales. I want to eliminate paper and it is helping with this task. Finding the right apps to assist has been time consuming but all in all I am getting there. The SD card allows me to carry all my customer files with me along with literature and demonstration videos. Expansion, replaceable battery, and price point for what you get are the biggest benefits over the competition. Easier to access and much lighter than a lap top. The only down side is the battery time. This is not a negative of the Thrive specifically. My usage would go through any tablet battery. If I am not using it - it is being charged to insure no interruption. Overall I am very happy with this product and would recommend it to a friend or family member.

Item.ReviewTitle: Adds weight but would buy again
Item.Review:
Pros: Does What It Claims
Cons: Adds weight; Small keyboard
Purchased to use for typing rather than using the Android on screen keyboard. Was reasonably easy to connect; syncs without problem. It does almost double the weight of an already heavy Toshiba Thrive. As a result, we attach and remove depending upon the use. I have some difficulty using the smaller keyboard with my large fingers. Problems primarily occur when hitting Cap Lock while trying to hit letter "a" and trying to hit right shift key due to placement on keyboard. My wife seems to be able to use easier than me with her smaller fingers.

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review: Bought this at Best Buy on sale a few days ago for almost half the price of an IPad 2. This thing works great and you're not stuck with Apple's proprietary junk. The Android 3.2 OS is wide open for any developers to write any kind of program they want, so there are going to be tons of apps for this(there are already a bunch). And you'll even be able to view web pages with flash content(something IPad2 can't do). Has a built-in full size HDMI, and USB, which is awesome(have to buy an adaptor cable for IPad 2). And it has a full size SD card slot to upgrade storage(Have to buy an adaptor cable for IPad 2). This is the best tablet out there for the money, and it even wins over much more expensive 10" tablets. And the extra thickness is an attribute...it's much easier to hang on too, and feels ... solid with the rubberized back. And the battery(which is easily removable/replaceable) lasted 10 hrs last time I used it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Toshiba Thrive AT105-T1016 16 GB - EasyGrip finish in black
Item.Review:
Pros: Flexibility; User-replaceable battery
Cons: Somewhat Thick
If you like flexibility, this is an excellent tablet. It has industry standard ports, so you don't have to play around with proprietary connectors. It has decent battery life. Also, unlike virtually every other tablet, you can pop the back cover and replace the battery. This is a pretty cool option if you're going to be away from a charger for an extended period. I also like the feel of the back cover... it's very "grippy." Pairs easily with a bluetooth keyboard if you're going to be doing serious typing. The tablet performs well, overall. If you're not fixated on having the thinnest, lightest tablet, this is a great product.
